job_title: Call Center Representative in Norwell, MA
pros: The ability to work full-time from home
cons: The pay for this role could be better. Industry standard is more in my opinion

pros: SSH is conveniently located in Weymouth
cons: SSH is short staffed at the moment.

pros: Flexible work schedule , you learn a lot, lower level managers are supportive.
cons: Less pay than other clinics around doing the same thing. Usually short staffed

job_title: Home Health Registered Nurse in Rockland, MA
pros: High level of autonomy with patient visits.
cons: Heavy case loads, "on call" shifts were actually fully scheduled working shifts due to short staffing.

pros: Great commute if you live on the South Shore.
cons: Leadership is weak. VP-level and up is paid very well, to the point of too well. They do not invest enough financially in non-management staff. Long-time staff are not open to new ideas.

pros: great benefits that build up '''''' employer match''''family oriented

cons: Shuttle if you work in main building

job_title: Information Systems Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Local community hospital, felt really good to be working in and for the community I lived. Some really passionate people there and my team was great.
cons: Leadership. Condescending, mean, had no interest in my wants, needs, or work/life balance. Made demands, yelled. It was a hostile workplace for many people. In my 3 years there many people left.

pros: Good location without the hassle of driving and parking in the city. Love the working relationship with our Pediatric Hospitalists who are Boston Children's Hospital affiliated. That coupled with our skilled respiratory therapists allows us to care for patients who would otherwise have to be cared for in a step down ICU.
cons: Healthcare in general is a challenging field to work in during these times due to staffing and supply shortages

review_title: If you love what you do
pros: Learn a lot, good starting pay, team oriented, good benefits, caring staff and management, many resources are offered from financial help to well-being
cons: Nurses/techs can be cliquey, I was laid off for not fulfilling a per diem status, and now can’t be hired back to the same company under a different job title (post college). The location in which I worked did not allow me to continually maintain this status because they were fully staffed (3 Nursing Assistants) and I was not needed. Because I was hired for that location only I could not pick up per diem hours at the main hospital because I did not have training to do so. I asked every chance I got to be cross trained during my 2 years at South Shore Health and was turned down every time.

pros: There is the sprit of community like you have in smaller facilities and the exciting challenges you have working in a larger facility.
cons: I honestly don't have any cons to list

job_title: High School Admissions Representative in Hingham, MA

pros: 3 shifts per week, great people to work with
cons: Low staffing/patient ratios with the RN shortage like everywhere else.

pros: yes good not bad at all

review_title: Inadequate training/consistently understaffed/high staff turnover/changing roles/job without notice or input
pros: The patients, rewarding work, filling a great need.
cons: Stressful work environment due to poor morale and understaffed, transactional management, pressures every day to take more than assigned workload. Frequently being contacted during off hours to work/asking to do more due to inadequate staffing. Directors are not friendly or care about employees personally or professionally.

review_title: up and down over the years,depending on the mood of management
pros: lots of nice people to work with
cons: management needs to acquire skills in dealing with employees as people first
